pageContext.claim: “We’re going to be talking to them. We're continuing to talk. We've been [in Afghanistan for] 19 years. We've done tremendous work. We could win it very quickly if I'm -- I've said this many times -- if I'm willing to kill 10 million people in the course of a week or two, we could win that thing very quickly. I'm not looking to kill people in that case or in any other case, frankly. We could win that very quickly. It has not been easy for our country because we're really serving as policemen more than we are anything else. We're like policemen in Afghanistan. But we're talking to the Taliban. We’re talking to the government.”
pageContext.analysis: The U.S. has had a presence in Afghanistan for 18 years. Trump’s suggestion would wipe out one-third of the Afghani population and many experts believe would require nuclear force, which would be a shocking and unprecedented world event indistinguishable from genocide. Still, there’s no guarantee that such an extreme move would ultimately lead to a stable Afghanistan.
